headline: King Charles
subHeadline: Rep. George Santos (R-NY) Facing Potential Expulsion From Congress; Rapper's Lyrics Used As Evidence Against Him In Trial; KING CHARLES Maiden Episode. Aired 10-11p ET

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much for joining us from Tel Aviv. A new kind of conversation with Gayle King and Charles Barkley is starting right now. KING CHARLES and its premiere begins now.

utterances.speaker: GAYLE KING, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: KING CHARLES starts now. Welcome, welcome. I like how that started, Charles Barkley.

utterances.speaker: CHARLES BARKLEY, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: I am so excited. Great work by the crew.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Me too. Thank you, crew. We thank you so much for joining us tonight. This is KING CHARLES, our brand new show right here on CNN.Now, just seeing the two of us should tell you that this is going to be something a little different. Wouldn't you agree?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: That's an understatement.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: That's an understatement? How?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: But it's going to be fun.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: How so? How is it an understatement?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Well, because we're going to have fun. We're going to give opinions. We're not going to be opinionated. We're going to give opinions. That's a difference.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Right. But I'm already a little worried, Charles. I went to the dentist today and I was leaving, a woman came up to me and she said, Gayle, I'm really excited about your King George show with Charles Barkley.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Listen, first of all, I just want to make people think I'm not calling myself KING CHARLES. It's Gayle King and Charles Barkley.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: There's a method to our madness.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes. KING

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: That's me.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Some of it will be both. Because, frankly, we think that's sort of life, don't you think?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Well, it should be fun, but sometimes we got to be serious.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: That's right, and we know how to do that. Hopefully, this show will be a place for people who care about what's going on in the world, but also a place for people who might just need a bit of a break. And I'm thinking, we all need a break these days.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: We definitely need a break from life today.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Because the world is nuts.And this show, by the way, isn't a one-way street. We want to hear from you. So, we're asking you this. Please leave us a voicemail. Ask us anything. And, Charles, we have our own number. What is it, dear? What's our number?

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Okay. Now, tell people what that number means.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't know what the 855 is, but 3434 is my number from Phoenix and Philadelphia and from my special friend, King.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: And look how cute you look. How old were you in that Sixers uniform?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Probably 26, 27.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: 26, and you lost a mustache when?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Well, when I realized it was ugly.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Okay. And then how old were you in this --

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Very nice. Very nice.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Those are called the good old days?

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: I really like it.Tonight NBA head coach of the Golden State Warriors. I'll bet you know him, Steve Kerr.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Great coach, great person. KINGPlus, we'll talk about a Georgia trial. A lot of us are talking about this. It's got huge implications that does not involve the former president. And the two people who say they have the best jobs in media right now are here.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, we are.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Besides us, I do think we have one of the best jobs in media, no kidding. Beyonce and Taylor Swift's new national correspondents are making their T.V. debut tonight.But first, Charles, we got to talk about this. Roll tape. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) REP. GEORGE SANTOS (R-NY):  There's people with all sorts of shiesty backgrounds and all of a sudden, George Santos is the Mary Magdalene of United States Congress. I will not be resigning. Are we to now assume that one is no longer innocent until proven guilty and they are in fact guilty until proven innocent or are we now to simply assume that because somebody doesn't like you, they get to throw you out of your job? [22:05:7] REP. RALPH NORMAN (R-SC):  The American people aren't worried about George Santos. They're worried about what they're paying for gas. They're worried about what they're paying for eggs. REP. MIKE JOHNSON (R-LA):  What we've said as the leadership team is we're going to allow people to vote their conscience. I think it's the only appropriate thing we can do. We've not whipped the vote and we wouldn't. I trust that people will make that decision thoughtfully and in good faith. I personally have real reservations about doing this. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Okay. Trips to Atlantic City, casinos and the Hamptons, shopping at Hermes, Botox and purchases rather on OnlyFans. Charles, do you want to share about your OnlyFans account?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: I don't have one of those.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: I don't have one of those.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Okay. Just checking.According to a House Ethics Committee report, that's just a day in the life of New York Congressman George Santos. So, where to begin on all of this? We brought in Van Lathan of the Ringer's Higher Learning Podcast and the host of Laura Coates Live. Hello, Laura. Laura Coates is with us now to help us sort it all out. So, there's a third attempt to expel the Congressman Santos right now. You kick it off, Charles. What are you thinking?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: This story makes me sick to my stomach, to be honest with you. First of all, it shouldn't take three attempts. Gayle, there's no job in the world where you could lie that much and keep your job. There's not a normal person watching this show who would go to a job and just tell complete lies, and then they found out about it and they would keep their job. I don't understand why it would take three times. I mean, this just shows you how broken our political system is, because you can lie that much and keep your job.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Yes. But people say you're innocent until proven guilty.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Well, you've been proven guilty.

utterances.speaker: LAURA COATES, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Well, he has the Ethics report. I admit, I mean, the receipts, first of all, the receipts, the Botox, is it Ferragamo, is it the idea -- I mean, I can't afford Heremes, why I would mispronounce it every single time. You also have the OnlyFans.I mean, everything about it, he is defiant and he is saying and he's daring everyone. He's saying, put up or shut up because you might, down the line, have some allegation against you and they're going to expel you. Now, it won't be the same thing, but that's what he's holding onto, this sort of slippery slope attitude (ph).

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: But it makes me think, though, guys, that there's no shame.VAN LATHAN, CO-HOST, THE RINGER'S HIGHER LEARNING PODCAST:  There's not. But that's -- I mean, that's where we are in America. I love him. I should be honest with you.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: You love George Santos?

utterances.speaker: LATHAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. So, I didn't like him and then I found out that he spent $400,000 on OnlyFans, and I'm like, that's me. You know what I mean? And so I'm like, that's like my guy.Look, you guys, America has to come to grips with who we are. We think that we're Barack Obama, this super polished, educated guy who never says anything wrong. But, really, right now America is George Santos. We are the OnlyFans freak who is going to the casinos and doing all of this stuff. I think he's the perfect mascot for political dysfunction. I want to see him stand around for as long as he can.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Van, do you think political scandal is now normalized at this point? Is this where we are today in America?

utterances.speaker: LATHAN
utterances.sentences: Well, it's always been normalized but it's never been sensationalized to this degree. You've always had Gary Hart, you've always had, you know, the Kennedy brothers.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: But that wasn't considered normal back then.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: It wasn't considered normal. This is more normalized but I think we've lost our way a little bit and I think we need a mascot for it.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: First of all, If George Santos and lying like he is, is American, I must not be. I must need to check my passport again. It's not a normal thing what he's doing.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: There's a couple of things. I do think you're right, the reason other politicians don't condemn him, they don't want us looking into there what they're doing with their money on the side. That's what I truly believe. Because there's no way, all that stuff, the fans only, nothing, spending all this money, they don't want us looking at their bank accounts where their money goes.But my biggest problem goes back to, you shouldn't -- you can't get elected lying like that. That's my problem with the whole thing. You should not -- you should get -- everybody else will get fired from their job. And we're not talking about the stuff you're talking about. Like he lied about where he went to college.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: He didn't have any of those. He didn't even go there.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: He didn't go there. He lied about where he worked.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: He didn't work there.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: He didn't work there.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: That stuff had been proven.

utterances.speaker: LATHAN
utterances.sentences: Can I be real with you, though?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LATHAN
utterances.sentences: Once again, I mean, I'm not making excuses for George Santos. I actually think that's kind of normal. I think if you look at people, they lie on their resumes. They lie about who they've been with.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's a -- no disrespect. That's to get a job at a fast food restaurant.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: I mean, I may have lied about my weight on my driver's license, but everyone does do that. But no one is talking about the rest of it.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: You really do believe most people lie on their resume?

utterances.speaker: LATHAN
utterances.sentences: I believe that most people are in their resume.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: I don't need to. BARKLEY

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: I think people -- Van, I think people embellish sometimes, but I don't think the extent of his lies, that's what I think. And I think the fact that he has doubled down and says I'm not going anywhere. That's what I don't get.

utterances.speaker: LATHAN
utterances.sentences: Let me be serious for a second. I think that the campaign finance -- the campaign finance irregularities and things like that, I think those are serious issues. I do think there is a part of this that is the policing of the quirkiness of George Santos that makes him an easy political target to me in a climate where there is so much rampant lying, misinformation and misleading of the American people, that he's being scapegoated in a way. I don't like --

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Well, most in fairness, though, Van, most people lie after they get the job. They don't lie to get the job, you know, yes. He lied to get the job and he continued to lie. Most politicians, they don't start lying and become crooks after they get the job. That's my problem with this whole fiasco.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: But I think you're onto something, though, Charles, when you say people aren't really -- some of his fellow colleagues aren't criticizing them because they don't want them looking -- they don't want them to look at what they're doing.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: 100 percent.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Because George Santos is sort of implying that if he goes down, he's not going down alone. He's already said the other day, yes.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: He is very clear about that threat. And I bet, of course, there are skeletons in the closet of many members of Congress. I'm sure we can find that, which is why part of the reason here people have criticized the media, because the fact that we're finding out this stuff through the Ethics report or after the election at a time when, normally, when you had local newspapers that were flourishing at a different time and everyone wasn't turning towards television for all their news all the time, you had vetting. You had the opposition research from the other candidate that would have found this stuff out.In fact, his own campaign found out a lot of this stuff, but they still allowed him to get there. And as the people of his district are now suffering because it's probably going to flip back once he's not in office.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: The vote to expel is going to take place this week. Let's go around. Would you vote to expel, Laura?

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Oh man. Really?

utterances.speaker: LATHAN
utterances.sentences: I mean, they're not going to do nothing to Congress. We might as well be entertained, but, yes, I vote for expel.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: We welcome you back, welcome the people back, Charles, to our debut show.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes, welcome to KING CHARLES.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Yes, we are so glad to be here.All right, this is what we're going to do now. Play something for you right now that many people think of simply as music or art. And we're asking you to please keep an eye on the lyrics at the bottom of the screen because prosecutors are calling them evidence. Now those lyrics from Just How It Is, a song by Grammy-nominated hip- hop artist Young Thug, were quoted in the indictment for racketeering and gang conspiracy charges the rapper is currently facing. And the judge says this, that prosecutors are allowed to use these and many more in trial. Well, that has a lot of people talking. Back with us to break it all down bar for bar, we're so glad Laura Coates agreed to stay. Laura Coates, by the way, she's a badass. She happens to be CNN's chief legal correspondent. You're going to be on the air later on tonight.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Thank you. I am. I'm happy to be in this fabulous show.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: And Grammy nominated hip hop artist, author and entrepreneur Fat Joe is here. Fat Joe, we're so glad you're here.FAT JOE, GRAMMY-NOMINATED ARTIST, AUTHOR AND ENTREPRENEUR:  Thanks for having me. BARKLEY:  So, we want to start with you because you've been behind the push to stop this kind of prosecution. What's your reaction when you see that he's on trial, accused, and that his lyrics can now be used against him in this trial?

utterances.speaker: FAT JOE
utterances.sentences: That's horrible. It's a travesty. I've been rapping professionally for 30 years. I've lied in almost 95 percent of my songs. I'm being  -- lied. Like just go -- I write like I feel that day. I'm just being creative. You know, you could probably put -- you couldn't build the jail high enough for the lyrics I've said on songs, which are all untrue. What I am is a family man, the person who gives back to my community all the time, open businesses in my community. So, the music would never amount to the actual person Joseph Cartagena.So, what's even more horrible is that the district attorneys, they know those lyrics ain't real. They know that's creativity. But if it helps their case, they'll use it to put these guys in jail. And here, we're having a fun show about it in discussion, but there really is six defendants in Atlanta who might spend the rest of their life in jail for something that's totally not true.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Yes, you're saying this is not a laughing matter. This is very serious.

utterances.speaker: FAT JOE
utterances.sentences: This is very serious. This destroys families. This destroys -- I would say those guys got at least 100 people that are employed by them that they pay their bills. No Thanksgiving for them, no Thanksgiving for the 100 employees.And this case right here is setting such a precedence in America, because they've used this before in up and coming aspiring artists. They never took a guy off the stage in the arena. You know, a number one artist that my daughter and all the kids look up to and say, no, you're going on trial for this. And it's nasty work, it's real nasty work.

utterances.speaker: FAT JOE
utterances.sentences: Let me play devil's advocate with you. How was your client, if you were the defense attorney, did you think that this was right using these lyrics against the client?

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: No. You know what I would do if I was a defense attorney, exactly what they're doing, which says, he is just an artist. I can no longer charge him as if you were to say, I'm going to charge Picasso, because he didn't accurately depict the way the dimensions of the face actually should look. It's an artistic license. However, you got that RICO charge.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: What about freedom of speech?

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: That's going to be the argument, but that's not what they're talking about here. They're really saying, you are free to say what you're saying, but you're not going to be not liable for what you have said. If I were to hire somebody as a hit man, I had the freedom of speech to say it, but I can be prosecuted for having asked the person to do it.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: But don't they have to actually hire a hit man and somebody to die?

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: That's the thing about RICO. I don't have to actually carry out the crime. It's like the mob boss crime everyone talks about, but that's where the issue is.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: But most of the time, RICO is used for the mob.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: It is. That's what they're talking about, YSL (ph).

utterances.speaker: FAT JOE
utterances.sentences: Well, it started that way, you know, because there's always an excuse to go after a law. It starts out with the mob, and then it comes down to the black and the Latino community, and they slay it (ph).

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: And the former president is also in a RICO case too, Laura, he's also in a RICO case.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Yes, absolutely. This is why everyone is not only because it's YSL. Not only because of what are present reasons you're talking about, Joe, and that really is the crux of this case that people are talking about it, but also because it's the same crime that Donald Trump was charged with, and it's the same D.A., Fani Willis, who is looking at this case and everyone saying, how is she going to try this one to figure out the rest?But it's different because there are states like your own hometown in New York that are saying, you should not be able to use rap lyrics to get somebody in prison. That's the artistry.

utterances.speaker: FAT JOE
utterances.sentences: But it's the truth. Martin Scorsese should be in jail for 10 million years. Arnold Schwarzenegger was the governor. He should be in jail for 20,000 years. If we're going to take everything that's offensive -- KING

utterances.speaker: FAT JOE
utterances.sentences: Because this guy killed 10,000 people in movies. So, it's like if we're saying, I'm telling you I lied for 20, 30 years of my life on music, just being creative and telling stories, how could you be charged for your imagination?

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: But one of the things the prosecutors say too, Joe and Laura, help me with this, they say, the things that he rapped about have actually happened. That's one of the arguments, the things that they rap about.

utterances.speaker: FAT JOE
utterances.sentences: If you're a gangster rapper, whatever you are rapping about happens in every intercity and if you can make it close enough, then you can use that to your advantage. The truth is, if you really want to put these gentlemen in jail and they're really criminals, use real evidence. Use real facts.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: But they're saying, I could have rapped about it, but that doesn't mean I did it. I've seen it, I know about it, but it doesn't mean I did it.

utterances.speaker: FAT JOE
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Do you ever felt compromised, I mean, as far as like ever worried?

utterances.speaker: FAT JOE
utterances.sentences: No, because, you know, minds don't add up. Minds don't add up. But this definitely puts vulnerability once again to all rappers all around the world up and coming. And not only that, the one thing I agree with you, Laura, and you're very intelligent, is I do believe that freedom of speech is on trial in America right now. We're using the face of a rapper, but this is freedom of speech on trial.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Do you feel that it's just the rap community that's under fire? Because there have been other genres who have talked about violence.

utterances.speaker: FAT JOE
utterances.sentences: Shot the sheriff, you know, mama, just killed the man.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Bohemian Rhapsody, yes.

utterances.speaker: FAT JOE
utterances.sentences: You know, it's just so many songs, you know, but it always targets the rap community. So, that's why we got to be very, very careful with the youth and they got to really take notice to what's going on right now with this trial because, once again, this has been used against artists before, but that's artist Joe Schmoe. They went and took the number one artist in America and put him on a RICO trial. I mean, this is unheard of and they're doing this because I'm watching the trial every day on YouTube. This is on T.V.

utterances.speaker: FAT JOE
utterances.sentences: I don't know how a number one rapper in America and could run a criminal enterprise. I just don't know how that works. This guy is on tour. This guy is making music. This guy is hiring people. This guy's shooting videos. This guy is doing an award show. But to say he's John Gotti is -- because that's what we're saying, right? That's the RICO. Like I can't see it in that way.Now, I don't know this young man. I don't know. I'm here on the issue of freedom of speech. So, I can't tell you what evidence they do or they don't have. But I know RICO itself is like the easiest case to convict in the world. And then you got the lyric, rap lyrics, it's like, man, the fix is in. Like, you know, it's like, it's a walk in the park.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: So, you're very worried about this?

utterances.speaker: FAT JOE
utterances.sentences: Yes, it's an ugly case. You know, it's an ugly case. You know, Atlanta's a tight-knit community. And so everybody knows everybody over there. Even though it's a big city, everybody knows everybody over there.And the fact that you have to always keep in mind is the human factor. There's jealousy, there's hatred. You know, I've seen it myself.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Racism?

utterances.speaker: FAT JOE
utterances.sentences: Yes, racism. I've been in places where, you know, I've watched police officers look at me like, yo, why is he eating steak and lobster in here? Why is he drinking champagne and walks past all of us? So, it brings some type of envious and jealousy to it. So it's going to be --

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: And this trial is just getting started and all eyes on it.Joe, thank you so much for coming in today.

utterances.speaker: FAT JOE
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Gayle. I love you bubblegum pink.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Well, she wants to be known as magenta. That's when you know you got money. You make up your own --

utterances.speaker: FAT JOE
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Congratulations on the show. We know it's a hit.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Welcome back. We're excited about our next guest. He's one of the great people in the NBA. He's won five championships as a player, four as a head coach, but he reached the pinnacle of his life today being the first guest on the KING CHARLES show. Welcome Steve Kerr.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Welcome Steve Kerr. Listen, that's nine championships. Is that more than you, Charles?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Oh, that's nine more than me.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: That's nine more than you. Steve, we're happy to say he's joining us from the Chase Center in San Francisco. Steve, I have to say, full disclosure, you coach- One of my favorite player on one of my favorite teams, shout out to Steph Curry. Really, really, really love your team. And I think the world to you. We want to talk about that in just a second, but first we've all been watching hostages reunited with their families after the terror attack in Israel and the war that's followed.We thought that Steve Kerr would have a very unique perspective on this. Why some of you may not, some of you at home may not know about this, but Steve Kerr was born in Lebanon. His dad was Malcolm Kerr, was a professor there and president of American University of Beirut. Here he is in a 1983 CNN interview. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MALCOM KERR, PRESIDENT, AMERICAN UNIVERSITY IN BEIRUT
utterances.sentences: And now, of course, political controversy clouds many things, but I'd say that the main reason Lebanese, Syrians, Palestinians, Egyptians and others still want to keep in touch with the United States and still believe in contact and so on is because they know we've got things like this in our culture, in our society, that are really fundamental. Education, medical care, research, open doors.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Three months later in 1984, when Steve was a freshman in college, his father was assassinated by terrorists. So Steve, you bring a very unique perspective to this conversation. Big sigh, just looking at your dad on the tape. You know what it's like to lose a family member to an act of terror. And I'm wondering what your thoughts are as you're watching what's unfolding in Israel and Gaza.

utterances.speaker: STEVE KERR, NBA HEAD COACH, GOLDEN STATE WARRIORS
utterances.sentences: Well, it's devastating. And of course, as it's happening, it reminds me and my family of what happened to my dad. And so we understand the loss that so many people are feeling, both in Israel and in the Gaza Strip. It's just devastating. The atrocities of the attack itself, followed by 11,000 Palestinian civilians being killed, there's no way around it. It's just total devastation for -- for everybody involved and brings up a lot of really terrible memories for my family and me.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: I was wondering about that. How did you get the news about your dad? You're a freshman in college. How did you get that news?

utterances.speaker: KERR
utterances.sentences: They got a phone call in the middle of the night from one of his colleagues at the American University about 3 am and I just remember basically hysterically crying and not knowing what to do and it was just something that you don't wish on anybody.But you also, for me it gave me a perspective on life. Every time I hear about someone dying from gun violence, I think about my own experience and the shock and the pain that goes with it. And that's one of the reasons I've really taken on, you know, the gun violence prevention issue as kind of a pet project, something that I really devote a lot of time to.

utterances.speaker: KERR
utterances.sentences: Well, unfortunately, our democracy is not working right now, Charles, because if you look at the data, 80 percent of Americans, 80 to 90 percent of Americans want universal background checks, regardless if you're a Republican or a Democrat.70 percent of Americans think that weapons of military backgrounds, AR-15, semi-automatic rifles. 70 percent of us don't believe that American citizens should have their hands on weapons like those. But our policy don't reflect that. Our policies that the government has the power to put in place don't reflect the people's wishes. And so it's yet another issue in American society that's tied up in politics and money and power. Frankly, what we actually need is some Republican candidates to be able to run on a policy of guns violence prevention and not be kicked out of their party. If they can actually run and win elections with the idea of protecting American families, now our democracy will work. But we're too tied up in political turmoil for that to actually happen right now.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Yeah, and I'm thinking about the political turmoil in the Middle East because this war in particular seems to be so hard to talk about, Steve. Whatever your position, whatever your position, you're going to offend someone. And do you have any guidance on how we can navigate that? I'm wondering, because I've read that your dad really did believe in peace in the Middle East. He would get very excited about the prospect of peace in the Middle East. KERRfluent Arabic. When I was growing up, that's all I heard at the dinner table was that the Arab-Israeli peace possibility. I remember when in 1979, I was 14 I guess, when Carter and Begin and Sadat stood on the White House lawn. Camp David accords were signed, there was finally peace between Israel and Egypt. My dad was just flying high. It was the happiest moment I've ever seen him. So this was his whole career was based on the pursuit of peace in the Middle East. So as I watch it now, I wish he were still alive to explain the nuances. But my thought is it's all about the nuance. And unfortunately, in our society today, people don't want to recognize nuance. They want black and white. They want you're either on this side or that side. My advice to people, read Tom Friedman from the "New York Times." Tom Friedman is the foremost expert on Middle East peace. He's been studying this issue his entire life. All of his articles the last few weeks really examine the nuance, the fact that there are Israeli people who are desperately trying to help people in the Gaza Strip. There were Palestinian people desperately trying to help Israelis on that awful day of October 7th, get to safety. Humanity exists and you know that's the search we have to find the humanity within all this but it's so difficult given the atrocities and given the state of our world today and social media and how we sort of communicate together.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Yeah that's good advice about Tom Friedman you are spot-on about that.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: You know Steve number one I didn't know a lot about your dad but just listen to you speak about him and watch that little 30-second clip we've shown. You're talking about how happy he was during that time. Between him, Phil Jackson, Greg Popovich, you're talking about three of the most amazing men, sound like, been blessed to have in your life. How do all three of those men influence you?

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: And then you carry on that is the legacy of being incredible coach. You know many people who play under you have nothing but great positive things to say but I saw a comment about the game last night, Charles, you recall what someone said about the Warrior game last night?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: They're old, you know, what you know -- no and listen this is not personal with the amount of success that the wars have had Draymond, Clay, Steph, like people don't understand the NBA playoffs is like a two-month marathon and they've had so much success and everybody gets older when you have a lot of success. So I said I said two years ago I said it's gonna come down to the young guys on the Warriors and they let one of them Wiseman go.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Yeah, but didn't you make a comment about the Warriors last night? Didn't I see a post from you last night?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Good.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: About getting cooked?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Gayle, let me tell you something.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Did you see that Steve?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Steve, Steve.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Did you see that?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Gayle, Gayle.

utterances.speaker: KERR
utterances.sentences: I did not see it, but I'm okay with it. I'm used to Charles' comments, so I'm okay with it.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: You know, Steve, don't believe everything you read on the internet, because me and Gayle apparently hate each other.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Yeah, there is a story, yeah, but that's not true.

utterances.speaker: KERR
utterances.sentences: I also remember that Charles that -- No, I was gonna say I also remember you claimed you were misquoted in your own autobiography.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Yes --

utterances.speaker: KERR
utterances.sentences: I remember that.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes, yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: First of all, I said I didn't remember one thing Steve. Hey Steve, stop messing up the interview. We're having a great interview.

utterances.speaker: KERR
utterances.sentences: All right, you go on you go on.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Steve Kerr, thank you, thank you, thank you very much for joining us. We really appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: You have made it, Steve. You're the first guest on our first show. You have made it.

utterances.speaker: KERR
utterances.sentences: Hey, I am honored. And I miss working with you, Charles. And great to see you. Great to be with you, Gayle. Thank you, guys. KING

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Steve.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Cheering you on always.How's this for a dream job? The reason you're hearing "Wildest Dreams" by Taylor Swift. There you hear it right now. "Wildest Dreams" by Taylor Swift is because Taylor Swift and Beyonce now have their own official beat reporters. What's your favorite Taylor Swift song?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: I don't know a lot, but I'm going to just warn Taylor Swift one thing. Travis Kelsey is a good friend of mine. If she write a bad song about Travis, I'm coming for her. That's a threat. That's not a threat. It's a promise, Taylor.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: That is Beyonce's, you know it, "Run the World." And the answer to that question is well, her and Taylor Swift. Thank you very much. Listen to this, together, Taylor Swift and Beyonce won 44 Grammy Awards, released 19 number one hits, headlined 15 concert tours, and sold hundreds of millions of records. Already two of the most iconic artists of all time. Drop the microphone, please. So earlier this year, "Gannett," the largest newspaper publisher in this country, hired the first ever Taylor Swift and Beyonce beat reporters. Is that a dream job? Some people say, yeah, Bryan West knows Taylor Swift all too well. See what I did there?

utterances.speaker: BRYAN WEST, TAYLOR SWIFT REPORTER, USA TODAY NETWORK
utterances.sentences: I love the reference.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: You got that? And when it comes to reporting on Beyonce, Cache McClay is irreplaceable. See what I did there?

utterances.speaker: CACHE MCCLAY, BEYONCE REPORTER, USA TODAY NETWORK
utterances.sentences: I love that.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: You got that, Charles? You know those are two songs, right? Okay.

utterances.speaker: MCCLAY
utterances.sentences: Two good songs.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: We just want to keep him current, don't we? We just want to keep him current. Okay, so you guys beat out hundreds of people for this job. Tell me, you start us off, Bryan. WESTdreams, knowing that we could actually be reporters covering the beat.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: So you read an ad and said, I want that job and you went for it?

utterances.speaker: WEST
utterances.sentences: I was at CrossFit, so I love CrossFit, when friends texted me saying, your dream job just became available. So I had left news to focus on mental health and sobriety. And I said, the only thing that would bring me back is if I could report on Taylor every day. And it brought me back.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: And that's what you're doing every day.

utterances.speaker: WEST
utterances.sentences: That's what I'm doing.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: So do you travel to every concert?

utterances.speaker: WEST
utterances.sentences: I would love that. Actually, if we could just put in a word to do that. Right now though, I am just covering her, just like any fan. I've been watching the live streams, honestly, from one of my friend's closets until my place was ready in Nashville. And so just following the news and having sources, what I love about this space is I now have fans and friends that are in Argentina and Brazil who are kind of reporting from the concert and letting me know what's happening.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: How did you get the job, Cache?

utterances.speaker: MCCLAY
utterances.sentences: Yeah, well, I first saw it online and immediately I started like praying, because I was like- Praying? Praying, because I was just like, it just felt so like meant for me and I was so excited. And so once I got through the first round of interviews, I got a call back and I was just so emotional.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: What kind of questions do they ask you in the interview? I'm curious.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: How many times have you seen Beyonce?

utterances.speaker: MCCLAY
utterances.sentences: I actually only saw a Renaissance on her birthday in Los Angeles.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: That was your first concert?

utterances.speaker: MCCLAY
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: That's the one you went to?

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Yeah, yeah, in July.

utterances.speaker: MCCLAY
utterances.sentences: Oh, in July, yeah.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: So the big news in Beyonce land right now is Tina Knowles. Talk about a clap back of all clap backs because people were criticizing her, came for her after looking at her at the premiere of the Renaissance film, saying that she was trying to look white, which is just so outrageous. I call it fashion. But Tina Knowles really took on the haters. What did you think about that?

utterances.speaker: MCCLAY
utterances.sentences: I mean, I think she said it the best. I think to reach that level of stardom and success, I think it's very unfortunate that racism and sexism still exists. And I was, like any mother, I think Tina Knowles, clapping back, she was just protecting her daughter. And I thought the claims were ridiculous. I thought Beyonce was done.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Tina said every time she does something that she works her ass off for, and is a statement of her work, ethic, talent, and resilience, here you sad little haters come out of the word work, jealousy and racism, sexism, double standards, and you perpetuate those things. And she goes on and on, calls them clowns, calls them bozos.And I really appreciated that she took the stand. And she said, Beyonce will be pissed at me for doing this, but I'm speaking up.

utterances.speaker: MCCLAY
utterances.sentences: And I'm so happy she did. I couldn't agree more with everything she said.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Now, I'm just going to warn you. If your girl write a bad song about my boy Travis, it's going to be some furniture moving around here.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: People wonder if that's a real deal.

utterances.speaker: WEST
utterances.sentences: Yes. It's definitely the real deal.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: And Charles, do you think it's a real deal?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: I have very strict rules on mine and my own business when it comes to relationships. I don't have the courage to ask Travis, is it real? I'm hoping it's real, because he's a good guy. I've actually met both of these ladies, and they are so amazingly talented. I hope it's true, because Travis is a great dude.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Yeah, he seems to be.

utterances.speaker: WEST
utterances.sentences: What I would say with that is they are the it couple. They're the fairy tale that's playing out. It's a love story, baby. Just say yes. I find it interesting that it's a stark contrast to the last relationship. It was very much for six years, let's keep our private life private. Here you have now Travis and her being very public. She supports him at Kansas City Chiefs games. He's going down to Argentina. She's changing the lyrics to her song --

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: To include him. Yeah. WESTthink fans just love seeing something happy. Are they end game? I think it's possible. She sang that song to him while he was there in the crowd.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: So what's the line for you between P.R. and reporting? But Charles, I'm curious about dating high profile people because it was reported back in the day that you dated a high-profile singer.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: It's -- It's a --

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: It's a --

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: It's nerve wracking. You never get into peace and quiet. You have to worry about paparazzi all the time. And it just sucks.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: And the name was?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Stop it, girl.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Bryan, Cache, we are here.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: I love you, Gayle. We're gonna fight on our first night.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: No, no we're not. But it is a great story. Like I said, we're gonna be, thank you guys and congratulations. We're gonna be taking your calls and answering your questions here on KING CHARLES. And moments away, we've got our very first voicemail from, ooh, we already have a, Charles, we already have a mystery friend of the show.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: We got a friend?

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: As we've been saying throughout the show, we really do want to hear from you and we've got a special number just for you. I love our number, Charles. Say it again, please.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: And we think we're being --

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: -- KING.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: We think we're being clever because we took the 3434 from your number as an homage to you. I think that's nice. That was Bella's idea, one of the producers. I love that idea.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Well, she about time she came up with one good idea.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Leave us a message and we might play it for you on the air and answer your question. Just like this. Here's call number one.SHAQ, CHARLES BARKLEY'S FRIEND (on the phone): Hey, Gayle, it's Shaq here from Atlanta. I have a question. I'm just wondering why it's smart. Sophisticated person like yourself would agree to sit next to a dummy like Chuck all along for an hour every week. Anyway, let me know, Gayle. Love you. Bye.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Love you too, Shaq. I think that's his way of saying congratulations to you, Chuck, and that he has great love for you, and he's wishing you well. Isn't that what you took away from that?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: I love you too, big. That's what that meant.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think so, too.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: That was really cool for him to take the time. I mean, it ain't like he's doing anything. We only work one day a week. That was cool, though. I love the big fella. You know, I got a lot of love for him, Ernie, and Kenny. We have a lot of fun at work.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: But really, I'm really glad.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: This is my new gig now.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: I feel that way too. I'm glad that now we get the opportunity because you should know America, neither one of us was looking for another job. What attracted me to this was you.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: And same thing. I would only do this with you, Gayle.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: That's exactly what I said too.

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Listen. Shout out to our crew. This is our first show. We hope people like the show. We're gonna do our best. That's all we can do. We got a great cast around us.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: And if all goes according to plan, guess what? KING CHARLES is, well I know we'll be back next Wednesday. The question is, will you be back next Wednesday?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Well, I'll be here. We're on a special time next week, right?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: I'm not going to bed. I'm not going to bed.

utterances.speaker: KING
utterances.sentences: Should I stop asking you questions?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, you should.
